textBeforeTable: Aircraft load factors are used to measure aircraft in-flight capacity utilization. Domestic Aircraft Revenue Load Factors (monthly data, not seasonally adjusted) AIRCRAFT CAPACITY UTILIZATION - DOMESTIC PASSENGERS AND FREIGHT AIRCRAFT CAPACITY UTILIZATION - DOMESTIC PASSENGERS AND FREIGHT Mobility November 2001 » Transportation Indicators » BTS Publications » Home » Contact Us BTS Programs Organizational Chart Jobs and Internships Advisory Council on Transportation Statistics About BTS Statistical Policy & Research Scientific Integrity
textAfterTable: NOTES: The current value is compared to the value from the same period in the previous year to account for seasonality. Load factor relates to the potential capacity of a system relative to its actual performance. In order to combine passenger and freight to calculate overall aircraft load factors, a common metric is needed: ton-miles. Thus, it is assumed that a passenger plus baggage weighs 200 pounds. The data do not include international flights by U.S. domestic carriers or domestic flights by foreign carriers. SOURCE: U.S. Department of Transportation, Bureau of Transportation Statistics, Air Carrier Traffic Statistics Monthly, August 2001.
